segments.text: What is your full name?
Thank you for your full name.
What's your telephone number?
Full name.
Everybody calls you Mrs. Beathard.
That's all right.
Flossie.
Flossie?
I was Yocum.
Flossie Yocum Beathard.
Flossie Yocum Beathard.
Right.
That's B-E-A-T-H-A-R.
Right.
This is August 9th.
We're in Milano, Texas.
That's right.
We're inside a gas station grocery store.
We're talking to Mrs. Beathard, who...
I was born in 1904, weren't you?
Here in Milano, or was it right over there?
Over on Highway 79, over there.
I was born on one of the, what was it, the old Summers Place at the time.
My daddy didn't own any land at that time.
A little old rent house over there is where I was born.
Was your father a sharecropper?
No, no.
Well, for a while he was.
For a while he rented, and then he bought him a place, see.
They bought him 132 acres.
So he was able to be a renter and save up enough money to buy it.
Yes, yes he did.
How was your father involved with the mines?
He worked in the mine quite a bit.
He actually worked in the mine some.
Okay, and what was his name?
Walter, Walter Yochum.
Walter Yochum.
That's right, okay.
He worked in the mine, and also my grandpa McCoy worked in the mine.
He was Daniel McCoy.
He's the one that got hurt in the mind.
You know, I was telling you yesterday about some of it falling in on him and they brought him up and the company doctor was there.
They called him and my daddy was the only one that could hold him because he was in so much pain.
The others left.
They couldn't stand to see him in so much pain, see.
Do you remember about what year that was?
It must have been about 1906, about that.
You were about two years old.
I was about two years old.
Do you remember which mine you're on?
That was the big lump.
Big lump.
Yes.
Because part of that coal come out from under his place.
And my grandmother drew a little rod off that coal for many years.
See, back then there weren't any old age pensions at all.
And that helped her a lot, my grandma McCoy.
It helped her quite a bit.
And I remember she'd tell my mama, well, I got my money today.
And that, you see, I suppose the reason, one reason, he liked to work there.
And, of course, my daddy was his son-in-law, you see, and they sort of all worked together.
And then when my Uncle Dave got big enough, he went to work in it.
I see.
Well, did they have a foreman system, a gang system?
Something like that, yes.
Sort of a straw boss, you know.
One that kept books, too, you know.
And...
And we're speaking about the people over there, those Mexican people.
A lot of them, they have pretty flowers in their yard.
Seemed like they wanted flowers and they'd have a little garden.
I remember the corn growing and their peppers, you know.
They're like lots of hot pepper, you see.
And they ground corn themselves?
I think so.
I believe some of them did.
And like I said, the young women, it was very dressy when they went out, you know.
And that was usually just on the weekends?
Usually on Saturday afternoons, you'd see them walk into town, you know.
They'd walk to Rockdale?
They'd walk to Rockdale, Rockdale.
And that was two to four miles?
Yes, quite a spell, you see.
Of course, some of them on up to Texas Mine, they'd walk up there, too, and we'd see them, you see.
I see.
They had their own cemetery, even, and it's still over there.
Oh, really?
A Mexican cemetery.
And when we'd come back home from Rockdale a little late,
And after they'd had a funeral, see, they'd leave candles burning.
And it sure would look spooky out there in that cemetery, you know, all those candles and flowers and everything.
It's still there.
Well, did the Mexicans have a separate church?
Yes, they did.
They had the Catholic Church over there.
The Catholic Church near the Texas Coal Company?
It is across the street there, the road, rather, from Big Blunt Commissary.
Most of them did go there.
Do you remember the name of it?
No, I don't.
I really don't.
What church did you go to?
Well, we usually went there to Sandy Creek.
Whoever was preaching it, you know, we'd go to the Baptists or the Methodists or the Church of Christ, you know.
Sounds good.
Just whoever you like to hear.
Yeah, we'd go and have those protracted meetings, you know, and have a week's meeting.
We'd go at night.
They had beautiful singing, you know, and we enjoyed it.
But the Mexicans even had their own school over there.

one of the vulgar girls taught school over there wow now that is later though gusta that's the vulgar she taught school i don't know if that's still living or not 1920s i really don't know somewhere like that i think yeah i know it's before i ever married so i don't know whether gusta and middle still living or not it's a pretty girl
You were telling me yesterday that your father cut timber.
Oh, yes.
Out of the woods, out of our woods.
Out of your woods.
Yes, yes.
And they had to be big, and they had to be pretty tall where a man could stand up.
And then they'd frame it from one big post to the other in there, frame it up, as they called it, to keep that dirt off of them.
So he would have to take the bark off of them?
No, they didn't have to be bark.
Just saw the edges smooth and have all the limbs cut.
They had to be, you know.
That's all right.
No, he didn't have to cut the bark off.
He used a cross saw to cut all this?
Yes.
He used an axe to cut them down?
Well, I think he sawed them down mostly with a saw, some kind of an axe.
But then the ends had to be tall and smooth, you see.
Did he do this by himself?
Yes.
Yes.
I've seen scars on his shoulders where he lifted them heavy things.
He must have been a big man.
He was.
He was a pretty good size.
Healthy and young, you know.
He didn't mind looking.
But I went with him here and everywhere he went, you know, helped him open gates.
You were his favorite daughter?
Well, they say I was, but because I was always hanging around, see, it wasn't that he really cared more about me than I was always there underfoot.
And if he got ready to go to Rockdale, I'd go harness his team up, see, his horse.
I knew how to put the harness on her, see, back into the buggy.
fix her up and get ready.
I could get ready to go in five minutes, and my older sister would take her hour, because she had to fix her hair all pretty.
Right.
Well, did you go to school in Rockville?
No, we went to Sandy Creek and Milano.
Sandy Creek and Milano.
Papa would send us a while at Sandy Creek, and then he'd send us to Milano.
I don't know why, but he did that.
How many months out of the year did you go to school?
Oh, about seven months, sometime eight.
But I remember I took Latin one year, and it was plum funny.
The teacher didn't know algebra.
They were going to teach us algebra to come at a time to have algebra.
She didn't know algebra.
She said, well, just take a year of Latin.
Now, you know that Latin.
It didn't ever do anyone any good.
She was going to make a pharmacist or a doctor or something.
Do you know what were the same courses offered in your school as were offered in the Mexican schools?
I don't really know, but I think so.
I think they were about the same.
I wish you could see Gusta, and ask her about these things.
But she's older than me.
She may not be living yet.
Gusta, G-U-S-T-A, Gusta Vogel.
She had a sister named Menta.
It's a pretty black-headed girl.
They looked Italian, but they weren't Italian people.
They were German, actually.
I think so.
I think so.
They were pretty.
Well, did you ever have social gatherings with Mexican miners?
Not really not, no.
Very little contact.
Very little contact with.
They was always friendly, and like I was talking to Simone Dowd and about it, I said, we never had any trouble with those people.
They were nice and good, most of them, see.
Seemed like they was all pretty peaceable.
And one thing to it, they was very devoted to their families.
Close-knit families, all of them, see, seemed like.
They didn't travel around much?
Not too much.
They just came to town on the weekends?
Came to town on the weekends, seemed like, go to church or something like that, you know.
Then you just didn't see them?
No, you didn't see them much, no.
You said something about that you and your father sold a truck farm to you?
Oh, yes.
Yes, we'd go through those camps, you know.
Well, he wouldn't let me go with him much when he was selling watermelons.
We'd raise watermelons, you see, and take them through there.
Sandias, Sandias, they'd buy those watermelons, don't you see?
Sandias is watermelons?
And we sold them cheap, but it was a little money in the summertime, don't you see?
Before the cotton got ready to pick.
So your father was mainly a cotton farmer.
That's right, that's right.
When did he quit farming?
When he got too old.
What about mining?
Oh, he didn't work in the mine very long.
When he got his land, he quit.
Okay, so by working in the mine, he was able to save his money to buy his land.
Well, no, not really.
He sharecropped.
He worked, you see, he rented the land, see, rented land first, you see, before he bought his.
And then he bought land that could be mine.
Mm-hmm.
Do you remember about what year he started mining?
Well, he just worked in the mine, you know.
When I was a child, a little, two and three years old, when he worked in the mine, you see.
And later, he done all I remember.
I don't even hardly remember him working in the mine, you see.
I remember Uncle Dave working in the mine.
And that was your father's older brother?
No, it was Mama's brother, you see.
Uncle Dave McCoy.
See, I was a yokel.
My daddy was yokel.
And your mother was McCoy?
McCoy.
Do you know where they came from, where the McCoys came from?
No, I really don't know.
I know more about my daddy's people than I did my mama's people.
He was Irish, and I think he had a blue uniform, which looked like, as we used to say, I believe he's a Yankee.
But I'm not sure.
He was a good man.
So he was born here in the United States?
Yes, oh yes, oh yes.
Did his parents immigrate over?
No, no.
They were born here also?
Mm-hmm.
Now, my daddy's people is different all the time.
Papa's daddy was about quarter Indian, and he was a Civil War veteran.
My grandpa Yocum, see?
He didn't like Yankees.
He was born in Virginia, and he was in the last battle he was in, the Battle of Gettysburg.
We were wounded.
So your grandfather was a Confederate soldier.
Right.
And your father was the Irishman you were talking about?
No, my grandpa McCoy.
McCoy, OK.
He was the Irishman.
I want to make that clear.
Yes.
McCoy was the Irishman.
And he was the Irishman, yes.
But we've got away from the mining.
You're not going to learn anything about it.
Well, that's all important.
We need to find out where everybody came from.
So my grandpa was born in Virginia.
Like I say, he got wounded in Gettysburg and had to walk home.
That's Pennsylvania, you know.
You see?
He walked home.
He was a big man, quarter Indian.
Do you think he'd done any mining in Pennsylvania before he came here?
No.
No, because he was born in Virginia, you see.
And he was carpenter and a schoolteacher, my grandpa Yoakum was, until he joined the rebel army, see?
He taught school and was a carpenter.
And then he came to Texas after school?
Yes.
Oh, yes.
Well, you know, back to the mining, how did the people of Rockdale and Milano view the mines?
It seems that most of this area is agricultural.
Were the mines a positive thing?
Yes, it was all right.
It was a help.
Some people, even, like I say, white people, worked there, and it was a help to them.
And they didn't resent the Mexicans, didn't seem like at all.
I know we didn't.
You want to go ahead and take care of your business here?
Oh, yeah.
It really is.
One thing I'm curious about, again, you may not know the answer to this, but that's all right.
But did your father and your uncle, did they sing in the mines at all?
Did the Mexicans sing songs as they were working?
I don't remember for sure whether they ever spoke of them singing there or not.
They're hard-working people.
I don't know whether they ever did or not.
But they had, they loved music, you know.
I think they had most of their music at home when they got home, you know.
You're talking about the Mexicans?
The Mexicans, uh-huh.
Yes.
I saw one place where, uh,
that the white families would hire the Mexican bands for parties.
Do you remember any of that?
Not really.
That must have been over around Rockland or where you see it.
I was over here closer to Milano, you know, in Sandy Creek.
Well, would you consider Milano and Sandy Creek more center
mining area in Rockdale?
No, I don't think so.
I think Sandy Creek and Rockdale would be more of the center of mining, because Sandow was down there way a long time ago.
Sandow, which is now, as you know, Alcoa.
And they had a Sandow mine down there a long years ago, you see.
They had that, they still have it, that Sandow Southern Railroad.
They still have that.
Once your daddy quit mining and went to cotton farming and agricultural work, did you have occasion to run into miners?
Oh, well, once in a while, some of the boys that worked in the mine went to school with us.
Oh, yes, the white boys.
The white boys.
Uh-huh, the white boys.
No, they had their own school over there.
But we wouldn't have resented them.
You know, I wouldn't have.
Did they have Mexican teachers, or were they... No, you see my second or third or fourth cousin, she was distal to Gustav Vogel.
She was a black girl, you see.
She taught the Mexican children.
And I have wondered, I guess she taught them English, you see.
Surely she didn't teach them Spanish, because they are, you know...
So you think...
That's where the young Mexican children learn English within their school.
Yes, I do.
Do you remember where the Mexicans came from?
Do you remember how they got to Mexico?
Not really, just like they do now, I guess, from Mexico.
See, we still occasionally have Mexicans around here that can't speak any English at all.
So there'd be illegal aliens?
Some of them.
But back then they didn't pay much attention to that.
But they weren't naturalized citizens.
A lot of them weren't.
Sure they weren't.
Did they seem to be happy with the day in the mine?
Yes.
Yes, it did.
I believe they were happy, yes.
Well, what happened when the mine wasn't operating?
What did the Mexican families do?
Well, it was muchthey operated for a long, long, long time.
And it seemed like if one closed or kind of slowed up, they'd just go over the other one.
I see.
You see what I mean?
Right.
So there weren't that many new people coming in and the same people moving from mind to mind?
I think so.
Do you remember any labor unions or labor troubles?
No, not really.
No, I don't think they had any trouble with them letting me get to this place.
Sure.
Right, so you did go, did you visit the Texas coal camp at all?
Just through it, just through it, you know, you couldn't.
My daddy would never let me around the mines at all.
See, the reason, I wish I could have gone, you know, into the mines, or close and let them work a little more.
Yeah, but your dad wouldn't let you.
No, no, indeed no, indeed no.
Well, it looked like two and three, two and three rooms.
Sometimes a little porch and sometimes no porch.
Sometimes they looked pretty bedraggled, pretty, you know, shackly.
Sometimes they looked pretty good.
You know, I think the company built those houses.
There's a few of them painted.
But I know they tried to look like, keep their yards clean, like I said, with flowers.
Very energetic people, it seemed like.

have their little gardens and things you know women were there any women that worked in mind no not really no no no they always had a bunch of children you know there's a lot always lots of children in the mexican families you know they're all you know catholics and they believe you know they believe in children right you see you know how young the children were they went to work for the mines
Or was there a law?
I don't think there's any law, really.
I think some of them could go to work at 15 or 16.
I knew a white boy that went to school over at Sandy Creek, and I think he was about 16 and he worked in the mine.
Because I remember he'd get his face all black, and he couldn't hardly get all that black coal out of the pores of his skin, you know.
It's hard to get clean.
Kind of like this coal over here at IGC in Alcoa now, you know.
It really gets in there.
How did your dad get the coal off of you?
Oh, he just, like the rest of them, just scrubbed it off the best he could, you know.
Was he in a strong lie zone?
Oh, no, no, no.
Well, you see, after they got grown, what I mean, really have a beard, a lot of that would shave off, really, you see.
Papa always went slick shaved.
And so they didn't really have much trouble with that.
They lacked a little money, and like I say, now that helped the people in general.
You know what I mean?
Yes, because... You say there's very few black people that work?
That's right.
Very few black people that work at the mine.
Did most black people just farm back then?
Yes, and farm, you know, and work for other people back then days.
Pick cotton for people and worked in the fields for them.
And you see, they weren't allowed to go to our schools at that time, you see.
They had their own schools.
They had their own church also?
Well, they still do that.
They still do that.
These people right here have got their own church right down here in this community.
Did the Mexicans and the blacks get together at all?
Not much back in them days.
They seemed like they weren't very sociable between each other.
Now, you know, there's always exceptions to the rules.
It's like you'd meet someone that you liked, someone you didn't, or something like that.
They didn't really mix.
I think the Mexican people thought they were just a little bit, I'll put it this way, above the blacks.
In the back, just the same way.
Each one was a little proud of his race.
We'll put it like that.
Okay.
If we go back to the mine sites that you did see, you were talking about the flowers and the particular attacks.
Did they have a cooking...

mostly of the inside mostly of the inside yes because we can see them stove pipes you know with the stove inside then of course like i say they they use lignite i'm sure because the smoke was too black would you think those were the old franklin stoves well just old iron wood stoves i think yeah yes but you see you could get them that burn wood or coal either one i had one at one time and it would they had the special coal grate in there you see i took the coal grate out and used wood
40, 50 years ago, back when I was sort of young.
Did you like to cook with lignite coal?
I never did get to cook with it.
See, we took that grate out of our stove and used wood.
I never did use the coal at all.
Why was that?
Because wood was... Wood was plentiful at that time, you see.
Everybody had their own way of getting their wood, you know, and preparing it for the winter and for the stove.
We had fireplaces.
What happened in the late 20s, early 30s, when the rest of the country was going through a devastating depression?
It was terrible.
There was a change here?
There was a drastic change here.
The people that owned their homes and already had their cattle, their chickens, their hogs, had a little money.
They'd done pretty good.
I'll tell you why.
Most of them, they learned to grow their own food most days.
their sweet potatoes, their ice potatoes, their fruits, peanuts, all of that, corn, make their corn meal if they needed it.
And we, and raise hogs and have their meat, you see.
So they didn't depend on store-bought things altogether.
Didn't take much money.
And the ones that had their own homes, done fairly well.
My daddy and mother did.
But some of them, you know, that didn't,
It's pretty rough.
Well, would the miners be in that category?
How did they get through the depression?
A lot of that had done slowed up then.
Excuse me.
I don't know.
You see, later on, we didn't have any relief for anyone then.
But later, they did have.
I don't know when it was.
In the 30s, I think.
Well, one thing I noticed.
Excuse me.
Sure.
Sure.
Around 1931, Rockdale was turning out the highest volume of lignite.
And I was just wondering how that worked in.
Well, it still helped.
It all helped.
And I expect the miners didn't suffer as much as the farmers.
Now, for instance, the people worked on the railroad.
They had their money.
They done pretty good, see?
People without jobs, though, it's rough.
They didn't own any land.
They didn't own their homes.
You see what I mean?
There's certain classes of people that it hurt worse than others, is what I'm trying to say.
You don't think miners were hurt that much?
Not really, no.
Do you remember when the first truck came to this area?
First truck?
Yeah.
Oh, man.
That's hard to say.
Did they use trucks in coal mines, or was it mainly railroads and mules?
Railroads and mules.
They had them little spurs.
They run a little track out to these mines, you see, to pick this coal up.
You see?
Especially little railroads, little tracks made, you see, to go out to these.
We called them spurs.
They loaded that on those cars.
And I think they took them over around Taylor, or somewhere, and shipped it off.
Alcoa, you see, it was Sandow then, they had their own railroad.
And they brought it out.
And these, right over at Big Lump, they had a spur.
I'd come in and picked it up, and over to Texas Mines and all, of Ogles and them others.
And the little old roads were sort of small.
Once one man got killed over there.
It was a white man, too.
One of them little coal cars ran over him and killed him.
Do you remember that when that was?
No, I don't.
I think it was in the 30s.
I really do think it was in the early 30s.
Guy Clymore.
Guy Clymore?
Mm-hmm.
He got killed.
C-L-Y-M-O-R-E?
Mm-hmm.
See, I can check that.
Yes, you could.
You can check that out.
One thing, did you ever go inside one of the commissaries?
Yeah.
What did the day look like?
Well, I was talking about that to Alvin this morning.
I said, there's two of them that I've been in.
I said, it looked a little like, part of it like the old-fashioned banks used to be, you know.
Them enclosures where, you know, it was where they paid their men, paid their people, and where you could pay for what you got.
You know, cages like in there.
Oh, I...
It is...
Wire, heavy wire, whatever you want to call it.
A grate?
Uh-huh, like that.
That's what I'm trying to say.
They had a little opening where they could pass money back and forth.
Where were the goods?
Oh, just stacked up around.
Just stacks of mostly general groceries, you know.
Did the people of Rockville trade at the concert?
No, no, not much.
That is mostly the miners.
But the miners did go into Rockville to... Oh, yes.
Oh, yes.
Because they didn't have to trade at the commissary.
They wasn't forced to.
It was just handy for them, see?
It was just handy for them, and they could buy their groceries there and save them going into town, don't you see?
And I believe the way they done that, too, a lot of times they could buy it, you know, and just take it out of their check, and they'd go to pay them, you know?
You see what I mean?
Were the prices higher in the commissary?
A little bit.
A little higher, yes.
Uh-huh.
I used to go over there at 12 o'clock to the Big Blunt commissary if I needed a pencil or a tablet or something from the schoolhouse.
And of course, I'd pick me up a little candy or something too, you know.
And right over here, like I said, I went over there with my daddy on the wagon loaded with those mining timbers.
And I drank my red soda water and ate my candy.
Yeah.
Quite a lot.
I can go right back through this road here, you know.
See, it was just a frame.
You took the bed off the wagon, you see, and you'd have to have just the frame, you know.
to carry those big logs.
I called them logs.
And then when we went back, I could ride that back cupton pole and have fun, you know.
You didn't help your dad unload them, did you?
Oh, no.
He unloaded them all by himself?
Yes, he did.
And then the miners themselves put the timber in there.
Oh, that's right.
They done that.
Yeah.
Do you know about how big the commissary was?
The ones that I was in is...
I balked a team.
A mule would go this way and then this way.
You ever see a team balk?
One would fly back and the other would pull.
The other would fly back and the other would pull.
And Papa laughed.
And the man looked around at him and took after him with a knife about that long.
And, of course, Papa shouldn't have done it, but he was laughing.
And he had to run.
He run and he got into that story in that commissary and he went on upstairs, see?
And the man was right after him.
With the knife.
With the knife.
And there's a black man.
come down and he says, stop right where you are.
He had a pick in his hand.
And my dad and you where they kept a pistol upstairs there, see, at that time.
And that's what he's going to go after.
But he didn't have to make it up there.
The black man had the pick.
But they picked Colway, you know.
Told him, stop right there.
And that ended it up.
I said, Papa, you shouldn't have laughed at him.
Well, he said it was funny.
I had to laugh.
That's a marvelous story.
Yeah.
Well, did you see any of the tools?
Nothing but picks.
Picks?
Picks.
You were talking about the hats yesterday.
Oh, yeah.
Little old caps, you know, with a carbide light that fit in on the front.
Were they cloth hats or metal hats?
No, they weren't metal.
They were just cloth hats that would come around, you know, just to hold that.
A little bill to it, you know.
Little things set up there and give them a little dim light.
Terrible work, all right.
But they seemed to be happy.
And there were no unions and no strikes?
No, I don't think they were.
I never heard of any trouble like that.
And that cave in, that was on that slope mine, and Alvin mentioned that to me this morning.
What, back in 1913?
Something like that.
And I had forgot about it.
There might have been some more tragedies over there, but I can't remember.
Well, I think that was the biggest tragedy.
Yeah.
Of course, I didn't know about it.
this uh white man getting killed yeah yeah now somewhere in the 30s i think a guy crime or yes he did he got killed there one of those coal cars run over it was it being pulled
